review_title: My worst job (review is school-specific rather than entire University)
pros: - I met some nice people
cons:
- Poor leadership within the school - didn't listen to employee's thoughts/ concerns and felt disregarded
- Seemed like there was tons of interpersonal conflict between many employees, faculty, and leadership - was a hostile environment and it constantly felt like "this person hates this person"
- The school has 6 programs with a 7th starting in 2023, but it seemed like they were just creating programs to get money, rather than wanting to provide quality education for students. The online program cannibalized the in-person, the full time programs received full attention over the part time programs. The part time students felt disregarded. (And yet they're surprised they can't hit their admissions targets)
- Poor communication from the top down 
- Lack of respect for individuals working hard - I heard some interesting feedback about people's yearly reviews (only a certain amount of people within the school could receive "Exceeds expectations" within a year)
- Lack of culture within the school. One of the loneliest places I've ever been.
- At this point, DEI seems more like talk than anything. Uncertain about tangible, actual practices. 
- Lack of work/life boundaries - supervisor would text at all hours/ all days
- Very much a "this is how we've always done it" mentality - opposed to new ideas

review_title: Zero career progression (run before it's too late!)
pros: Good retirement plan (if you started early enough), health insurance, disability insurance, nice campus and town (Davis is great! Wish my salary would allow me to live here), sometimes you get to work with smart people, employment stability, hybrid work schedule.
cons:
Very low salary, no career progression, insulting pay raises (if any, mostly only 1-2% COLA adjustments every few years), no bonuses or perks, nobody to learn from (a very siloed culture), bureaucracy, little knowledge transfer, not on the forefront of technological advances, any changes take forever to materialize, boring projects (CRUD galore).

As a staff employee, you are at the bottom of the barrel (the priorities at UCD are: Students -> Faculty -> Staff and nobody is even trying to hide it).

Be prepared for the diversity and inclusion agenda being brazenly pushed at you from all angles. And don't you dare have a different opinion about it - UCD values diversity of opinions as long as these opinions align with theirs.

Even though UCD is an educational organization, staff training is almost non-existent and if there is, you have to plan your own training. Nobody will help you build a training program that would suit your position/interests/capabilities and improve you career prospects.

If you are ambitious and would like to grow professionally, UCD is not the right place for you.

If you still decide to start working here, make sure you negotiate salary at the beginning of your employment, because you are going to be stuck at this level for many, many years.

review_title: A great source of discouragement for a postdoc!
pros:
- A lot of opportunities to increase your number of publications related to diagnostic subjects only.
- Friendly and cooperative staff.
- Great health insurance for self and family.
cons:
- Overwhelming with a lot of projects
- Your efforts is not appreciated
- You will not have weekends and holidays due to the PI pressure for working.
- You will be always micromanaged by the PI (if you are work in Diagnostic lab)
- Regardless of whatever work and effort you do, you are still seen as a perosn who has done NOTHING!
- You will hear repeated words of "I help you" from PI of diagnostic lab, but in action you will get NOTHING. This a very poor way of supervising a postdoc.
- Even as a joke, this is embarrassing, that you as early-career professional, you will be judged as a junior!
- Miscommunication is very common! So, you must be clarified almost everything and also try to WRITE everything down!
- Overall, the diagnostic lab management is really demanding and so ambitious! Instead of learning, you will be more serving!
I NEVER recommend this place for a postdoctoral scholar.

pros:
Experience. The primary reason to ignore earning little to no income during an internship is the knowledge of gaining actual work experience in a field you’re interested in. You’ll receive first-hand experience in a business-setting, putting you one step ahead of the game come the post-graduation job hunt.

Resume Enhancer. Employers are more likely to hire a graduate with the word ‘internship’ highlighted on their resume than those without. Taking an internship shows work ethic and a dedication to your career which employers find appealing.

Interesting. Due to the variety of tasks and projects you’ll be involved in as an intern, the work will never be dull.

Career Compass. As an intern, you’ll likely work with a variety of people in a number of different departments, helping you hone in on what you do and do not want to pursue in your career after graduation.

Networking. You’ll amass a decent rolodex after completing an internship, including a number of professionals who can help point you in the direction of a job opportunity or further connect you with the people who can.

Job Offer. It’s entirely possible upon completion of your internship your employer will offer you a full-time paid position, and while in some cases it may be a long shot, it is always a possibility that an internship can blossom into something more.
cons:
Unpaid. Most internships pay little or not at all, making it difficult for those without a wealthy benefactor to justify the opportunity cost of wages earned with paid work during the time period of the unpaid internship. This point is particularly poignant for those acquiring a sizable amount of student loan debt upon graduating.

Inequality. It is likely an intern will not be seen as an equal member of the staff due to the unpaid status. It is also difficult to shake off the label of intern when interacting with co-workers, even if an intern is offered a paid position at the conclusion of the internship.

No Focus. With the volume of tasks divvied out to interns and the varying nature of those tasks, it can be difficult to find a focus and goal throughout the internship.

Menial Work. The tasks assigned to interns are generally basic, low-skill duties, which rarely utilize the progressive skill level of the individual. While some internships provide an atmosphere for interns to put their specialty to use, most interns will acquire knowledge and experience relevant to their expertise by observing the paid professionals around them.

job_title: Student Assistant II in Stockton, CA
pros:
I worked at King's Hall Coffee Shop. At the time I worked there, King's Hall Coffee shop had their grand opening. There was an entirely new staff and we served our coffee differently (we had a different brand of coffee at the time, now it's Starbucks and there are a lot more varieties of sandwiches).

Now for Pros:
You get left over food and coffee!
- 15 min breaks you get a snack
-30 min breaks you get lunch
--if you have a good manager, you will not only have a good time, but you will learn a lot on how to coordinate with people (whether there are small or large groups of ppl) in a fast paced environment
-- you will also learn to work in a fast paced environment esp during rush hour
cons:
At Kings Hall... you have to empty out the sewage by the end of the day. All your waste that goes down the sink goes into the sewer tank located in the back of the building. It's not in your job description, but you really need to watch your back while doing this job. You not only have to tip the tank so you can vacuum all the sewage into another tank, but you have to haul it up the ramp into Kings Hall building into the janitor's closet to dump it out. 

I'm not sure if that is legal, but I think ppl should petition to fix that issue!

review_title: The only place you should be applying if you want to live in Davis, CA
pros: In Davis, you are either an employee of UCD, or you are nobody.  The town owes a lot to UCD and for that, you will be respected as an employee.  The university is very good about families, flex time, vacation time, etc.  I was excited to be in a community where so much research and teaching was occurring.  They push their employees and they achieve excellent research in many areas because of that.  The bottom line is that the UCD is a flexible employer, but at the same time demands a great deal of ingenuity and effort from its employees.
cons: It is VERY difficult to break into the ranks of the employed.  They promote a lot from within and this makes it difficult to even obtain an interview for many entry-level jobs.  They do provide good benefits compared to other universities but do not allow staff to take classes for free.  For some strange reason, they insist on using their own internal email program called geckomail.  I heard a rumor they were going to switch to google mail, but that is unknown.  Geckomail is bad, really bad.  Also, unless you are interested in working on plants, there are very few jobs in other areas of research.  UCD and also the town of Davis are very environmentally minded and always seem to be proselytizing about the environment, which can be frustrating when there are often more pressing issues at hand.

pros: Friendly academic environment, beautiful surroundings, great and affordable gym and sports facilities, international and multicultural diversity. Relatively easy to find jobs at an entry-level and by talking directly with the PI's.
cons: Salary rates are low and not competitive. The majority of the new hires are at the lowest salary scale possible and salaries are not raised on a yearly basis even if the performance reviews are positive (could be 5-years till the first salary upgrade and still this would only be $500 more per year). Some senior managers demand too much reporting and limit flexibility and creativity. There could be a lot of unrecognized scientific work and some PI's and even senior managers take ownership and credit for staff´s work and publish it without even aknowledging the real authors. University does not sponsor greencards for research staff (only for professors).

job_title: Food Service Worker in Davis, CA
pros: Very flexible schedule - the hours are actually fantastic for students. The coworkers are also very nice, I've made a lot of friends here. Also, seeing the freshmen is cool, because they're very sweet.
cons: So. Many. This job has a pretty high turnover rate - people get hired, see how awful it is to work here, and quit after one quarter. A lot of the times we're understaffed, and end up having to stay 30 minutes to and hour+ past our out time, which really sucks as a student. Also, the managers can be rude at times, snapping at you when you have to call out of work (when it's a legitimate excuse! Such as illness). Also, that's another thing. Everyone. Calls. Out. Especially when they're scheduled to work in the dish room, which is a disgusting nightmare. The work is boring, tedious and kind of painful. We're overworked and underpaid. Paid minimum wage but expected to put in extra work, when the work itself sucks. Doing the same bending, and moving motions gets old after a while. Expect to serve food for 4 hours straight, wash tables, refill napkins, handle nasty used dishes, stand for hours, carry heavy things, be treated like a robot by managers. Working late nights SUCKS. You get out anywhere from 1AM to 1:30 AM. I wish I could quit, but I'm poor and need money.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Sacramento, CA
pros: UC Davis is big enough to have a variety of laboratories in which you can work and study.  Funding varies by P.I.  Some amazing people and brilliant scientists live and work in Davis.  It can be a great community to grow in.
cons: Naive graduate students, beware.  Like anywhere else, there are great P.I.s and there are terrible ones.  Interactions with your boss should be respectful, of course, but don't defer to him/her without question.  Especially those who are new to their role.  Look at the quality of their publications.  Find labs with a consistent and timely graduation rate for their students.  Just because a P.I. tells you he has funding, does not mean it is true.  Do what you can to get your own funding, and cross check what the P.I. tells you with his staff and other members of the department and graduate group.

review_title: I met lots of lovely people in the community and worked with fellow college students in an energetic atmosphere.
job_title: Campus Recreation Youth Programs, Camp Instructor in Davis, CA
pros: This review is specific to Campus Recreation's Youth Programs. The camps run for ten weeks of the summer, so are ideal for students. It's good experience for tutoring or childcare positions later, but you will still need Early Childhood Education to get a better-paying job elsewhere. Within Campus Rec, most people come back for second or third years. If you want to take on more responsibility, it was easy to apply for Student Manager positions. We had lots of opportunities to make contacts with the UCD staff and admins who signed their kids up, as well as within Campus Rec. Can work full time or half time during the summer. During school year, can also volunteer to work at spring break or winter break camps for extra cash.
cons: My student manager was a first-timer and still figuring out the job, so our year-end reviews were basically the only feedback we got. I prefer more specific, one-on-one criticism and encouragement. I had a great experience, though. Not many cons come to mind.

pros: I loved working with my students and the community that I serve. There are not many spaces like this at a university, which is why the Student Recruitment and Retention Center is such an amazing place to be in.  All the work that happened were created by students for other students who are in their peer group.  Working with the youth and encouraging them to pursue higher education through non-traditional means is such a critical step in the development of youths.
cons: Staff didn't understand where different communities stands and were not as educated as they should be.  The Student Recruitment and Retention Center became a hostile and unsafe environment for some worker and there was nothing that they did to help it and instead further perpetuated the hostility.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: It's grad school, so pros are getting an education, some letters after your name, work experience, and network connections.  Pay varies greatly by department and where your money is coming from.  Manager style also varies greatly, so that could be a pro or con depending on who you work with.  The healthcare plan is pretty good and they offer childcare reimbursement now.  If you're able to achieve any work-life balance, Davis is nicely situated geographically near lots of things to do (beach, mountains, skiing, hiking, climbing, San Francisco, Napa Valley, etc.).  The weather is pretty awesome all year round (on the warm side, but fairly moderate and not much weather or natural disaster risk), and it's one of the most bike-friendly cities in the country.
cons: It's grad school, so you have no life, but that's what you signed up for.

review_title: This is an extremely frustrating organization to work for. This environment stifles creativity and achievement.
job_title: Public Education Specialist in Davis, CA
pros:
Stable Working Hours
Decent Benefits Package
Discounted Educational Opportunities
cons: Ineffectual leadership, bureaucratic processes, not mission focused or client driven, lack of transparency, incompetent staff and unprofessional staff are not help accountable, low standards equate to inferior products for clients, outdated systems stifle work flow, processes are not systematically managed, HR is completely ineffective, cannot retain talented staff, Infighting among leadership creates an unhealthy work environment for staff, Deans office is disconnected from client needs and end products being delivered, Suspicious financial practices with use of federal funds, merit is not rewarded, HR policies stifle wage increases, wages are far lower than campus equivalent positions, very unhealthy work culture

pros: Davis has a very small college town feel, but is near Sacramento and the Bay Area.  This allows for you to really focus on your studies during the work week, but to have some interesting adventures on the weekend.
cons: It seems like going here, people have a bit of a chip on the shoulder in terms of that we're close to the Bay Area, but not in the Bay Area, and the nearby colleges of note are Sac State, which isn't really discussed, or Berkeley and Stanford, which we perceive on looking down on us.  It's an odd sensation that doesn't come up very often, but I'm guessing everyone has had that feeling at one point or another.

pros: I worked for CRU for two years as an undergraduate. I loved it because the management staff was always considerate of a student's needs, and because all your coworkers were also students, everyone understood when you needed a shift covered or traded in order to study. You also got a discount at the bookstore, on cap and gown, and on one CRU program package. I wish I hadn't worked off campus as a sophomore because CRU was a much better fit and much better at working around my schedule. It was always a positive environment and I almost always had a great time working.
cons: The management changed in my second year which resulted in a complete shift of job responsibilities for all levels of employees. The end result was that I was responsible for much less than I had originally been charged with. I think for someone who came in after the change, it wouldn't be an issue. But because I had to relinquish a lot of the tasks I had been trained to do, it felt like a step backwards.

review_title: Nice when you're fresh out of school...but don't get stuck here.
job_title: Staff Research Associate I in Davis, CA
pros: UC Davis offers a generous benefits package to all employees, including health, dental and vision all covered for as low as $6.50 out of pocket.  You can also find relative job stability/security, particularly if your job is protected in a union.
cons: Unfortunately, you can also expect low pay (relative to private industry), slow career advancement, and no incentive for hard work.  Like most jobs associated with the state government, promotions are based on time served (and occasionally favoritism) rather than ability or achievements.  Recently, even cost of living raises were suspended, effectively halting the only form of raises some employees will ever see.

review_title: Great way to pay for your tuition bills
pros: I was lucky enough to work with great professors that care a lot for their students. I was given the freedom to create my own syllabus for a few classes that I taught. I enjoy the opportunity to impact the way my students learned about the subject I am teaching. I remember being frustrated with TAs I had in the past so I made sure that when I became a TA I didn't make the same mistake as they did.
cons: Many professor here are research oriented and they seem like they don't care too much about teaching students. Some of the stuff you lean here won't really matter in the real would unless you want to work in Academic setting. Some professors came be a little socially awkward and won't even say hi back when you pass them in the hall way. (might be a Engineering professor thing)

review_title: A good workplace to gain research experience.
pros: UC Davis has a large and beautiful campus. The cafeteria's serve good food. There's a variety of research going on and lots of events to promote that research. There are staff discounts for the amenities, but they're clearly not as good as student discounts. The insurance premiums were heavily subsidized.
cons:
Staff research positions like Junior Specialist or Post Doc are not meant for the long term (think 1 -3 year contract).  As long as you're okay with that fact then you should be fine.

Experiences probably vary depending on what department you're in, who your manager is, etc.  If there are cons, it comes from the fact that your work culture is dictated by your department or the research group you work in.

Also, there's a housing crisis in the city itself.  The university increases enrollment each year but the city doesn't build more housing so the rent increases substantially each year.  Nearby Woodland is cheaper to live, and some prefer to commute from Sacramento.

review_title: Great team, good tools, a bit cheap.
pros: The majority of people who work here are extremely decent, friendly and care about doing their jobs well.  It is pretty easy to learn all aspects of the business by talking to the various staff members.  The organization and its members actually care about sustainability and planning for the future, and also care about their residents.
cons: The pay is low and there was a serious disinclination to spend money on things like training.  Also, working remotely was only OK when it was in favor of the office (i.e. working while sick or after hours), otherwise all hours were to be in office, despite having no face-to-face interaction needed with those there.   Advancement seemed to come with either making friends with the director or gaining advanced degrees, rather than merit or applying for positions.

pros: Benefits, holidays,pension,allow you take learning classes related to job
cons: No job security.Charge employees $500+ a year for parking. Management is snobbish. No incentive to be an exceptional employee-bad workers and good workers receive the same the same raises and same treatment as good workers. Seniority based-they will layoff a great worker and keep a slacker.

pros: nice campus, pension program plus 403B, generous sick leave
cons: unstable funding future, layoffs, favoritism and nepotism among management. After being employed for over 8 years by the University, who lack dignity, I was forced into taking a layoff during a reduction in force, in which I held seniority over many other employees... Why you may ask?? Favoritism, management pulled strings to protect their personal friends in the department who had half the seniority. They took a loyal, faithful, hardworking employee and traded that to save pals who worked for them who called in sick whenever they got 8 hours accrued.... When it comes down to it, union backing or not, they can do away with you for whatever, whenever... An employee who not only VOLUNTEERED countless hours to training, PR,  but one who had NEVER received even a verbal warning, who had stellar annual performance reviews who had a total of 5 sick calls in over 8 years, and one who knew and LOVED the job.... Your loss UCD..

review_title: Decent place to work however management is very unprofessional
pros: Your co-workers for the most part are nice people. The hours put in are very flexible around your schedule and management is usually semi reasonable about things.
cons: There is a certain element of unprofessionalism that runs deep in the company. For example, when it comes to promotions and hiring a lot of times there is clear favoritism even before they have the interviews. Additionally, things that are supposed to be kept private such as reasons why someone was fired or penalized are talked about openly. Furthermore, a lot of times the person who is raised to management level isn't the most competent rather the most well friendly with the interviewers. In addition, there's a bunch of nasty rumors spread about people and it really feels like being back in high school.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Davis, CA
pros: It pays well salary wise, it is somewhat flexible on working times, and nobody micromanages your work.
cons:
Being a student with a UCD job, everything ends up going to pay the school back; as a TA you just have a guaranteed job for 3 months and no security at all for the next quarter; you could end up working more than what is was planned initially because the professor doesn't want to spend his time teaching classes...
There is a lot of instability if you are going to work quarter-to-quarter, there's a decent chance that you are not going to get a TAship, so do not depend on it (always prepare a second plan!).

pros: I got this job when I was finishing my PhD in Europe. I was quite motivated when I come here. The advisor was quite famous and has a strong record on some topics in which I was interested. The salary was also ok comparing to different postdoc fellows in the computer science disciplines.
cons:
The advisor was a really character despite his strong scientific record. He was a micro management freak who has the impression that all others are behind his back. He tried to put me on some topics that I don't have the chance to get any publications out. I learned he was also in trouble with his fellow grad students. This is my personal experience. 

On the other hand, Davis is a little bit isolated from the bay area, it is not well connected with industry which makes it harder to make a transfer from Davis to the Bay Area.

pros:
+ Plenty of flexibility with work hours and vacation time.
+ Faculty are friendly and are open to providing advice and guidance. 
+ Lab culture is very nurturing and promotes both learning and development of programming skills for bioinformatics.
+ Working on research projects and seeing them to completion so that they may be submitted for publications. This allows for increased experience in applying bioinformatics in modern research as well as scientific writing.
+ On campus food is always a short walk away.
cons:
- Salary will not be as generous as an equivalent position in industry
- For entry level positions (e.g. Junior Specialist) there is not a system of promotions.

pros: I have worked at the Sacramento Campus for about 6 months and I LOVE it.  Most of the facilities are beautiful.  A few are in need of updating but  only in comparison to the buildings around them.  There are multiple buildings that have cafes or cafeterias.  Walking to lunch is easier than going anywhere else and it is cheaper!  I start accruing vacation and sick days immediately and am able to use them after 2 months.  We get 13 paid holidays a year.  I have never worked with so many truly happy people.  I have not met one person that hates their job.
cons: You have to pay for parking and it is very limited.  You have to get here by 7:30 or you will have to walk  to your office.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: Excellent equipment, amazing visiting speakers, lots of brilliant researchers
cons: Poor internal communication on campus (collaborations missed, overlapping projects, etc); hard to navigate. professors not encouraged to be good mentors or teachers; too much administration and too many hoops to jump through with no institutional accountability for mistakes/oversights. you are absolutely just a number. exploitative policies for Teaching assistants and graduate researchers (as well as tenure track professors, lecturers, post-docs). Labs are run on the backs of the unpaid in every way and at every level. False career advice abounds because professors are too sheltered to know about current best practices. Far better as a technician, research scientist, or post-doc than as a grad student, but still hard to accomplish goals in the professional chaos. Sexism & racism vary hugely by department - be wary.

review_title: Heavy workload, but compensation is worth it
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Davis, CA
pros: Waived tuition, ability to work with students, a lot of freedom to pursue your own projects. The pay can become quite nice if you learn to be efficient with your time and energy. But really the big thing is having any kind of financial support while you go to school is really wonderful. You won't be going on a lot of vacations, but the support that UCD offers is enough to keep you afloat while you go through school, and that's about all you can ask for.
cons: There is surprisingly little teacher-training. If you want to become more efficient as a worker, and more successful as a teacher, then a lot of that responsibility falls on you to pursue learning opportunities on your own time. The UC system should push for higher standards (and support) for its graduate student teachers.

job_title: Animal Care Technician in Davis, CA
pros: Good benefits. Lots of training opportunities
cons: I worked at other places in the UC system and I found UC Davis to be the most mediocre of the ones I have worked. I found most of my colleagues are very adverse to any change whatsoever. They are mostly interested in maintaining the status quo and riding out the days til they can collect their pensions. You just don't feel inspired to excel like you might at some of the other top tier UC's and rather are encouraged just to keep things the way they are even if it is a wasteful and inaccurate way to work. Additionally the summers are intensely hot.

pros: Good compensation especially considering how many people are employed here with only very little, or no education  at all past high school.  Very surprising to me!  Great benefits, medical, work-life balance (depending on your supervisor and/or department).  Great opportunity to take UCD classes at a discount, and participate in other training development opportunities.
cons: Nepotism! It's all about who you know.  Discriminatory and racist practices get swept under the rug.  Many mid management positions are held by employees that have no, or only very little higher education, but have been with the University for years.  They are primarily interested in maintaining the status quo and feel threatened by more educated, newer employees.  Also, lots of wasteful spending of public funds!

review_title: Research Associate in Vet Med Lab at UC Davis
pros: Davis is a great little city.  The ambiance is great and the people there are really friendly.   I enjoyed working on cutting edge research, but found that I had a limited freedom to explore my own projects.  Maybe it was just because I was a research associate.
cons: There's not much to do in the town of Davis.  That's a really big downside.  You see the same bars and people at them over and over again.  Its a real college orientatied town too.  The closes big city is Sacramento, which in my opinion is one of the worst large cities in the state.  Take what I say with a grain of salt though, who knows you might enjoy it.

review_title: Abusive "Microaggressions 'R' Us" from smug population that refuses to think about their actions
pros: The people whose jobs are directly in service of the underrepresented tend to be good but having to run to them every time to get even a simple form taken care is soul-crushing.
cons: Davis people see themselves as righteous and progressive but are blind to their own privilege. They 'tsk' at anyone not exactly like them. There's a ton of subtle racism, sexism, and friction against the underrepresented. It's pretty soul-crushing to constantly have your emails and phone calls never returned when you're just trying to follow policy and do your job, all the while watching the people of the 'right' groups get responses. Try to talk to anyone about it and their response is always about how progressive they are. They will NOT admit they have a problem. Meanwhile I've been the target of ethnic slurs repeatedly.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros:
Job security - very stable, never heard of anyone being forced to leave prior to obtaining their degree

Flexible schedule - You can work any 60-70 hours a week you want!

Intellectual satisfaction - it IS cool to dig deep into a subject, and expand human knowledge.
cons:
No clear structure - Your boss (Primary Investigator) is likely juggling a ridiculous amount of responsibilities, so nurturing your growth as a scientist will likely take a backseat.

No positive feedback, financial incentives, or opportunities for advancement.

Relationship with administration is antagonistic. Generally, departments on campus don't know how to deal with graduate student status.

job_title: Clinical Nurse II in Sacramento, CA
pros: It's a Level I Trauma Center. Great experience. Lots to learn. Able to self schedule in the ED. Almost always get what I request as my work schedule. Very busy ER. Shift goes by fast.
cons: Supposed to be "zero tolerance of violence" at this hospital. But they are quite the opposite. Patients coming to ED are very abusive and the hospital does not stand by it's nurses. This hospital is afraid to "ban" patients from coming back.

job_title: Not A Good Place to Work in Davis, CA
pros: Good benefits as pertaining to vacation, sick leave-pension has been good but they are making changes to reduce that.
cons: Unqualified managers and supervisors in many departments. Childish game playing on many levels. The level of favoritism and nepotism is appalling. Very unprofessional environment. Also the University is in mass layoff mode, but the bulk of those being targeted for layoffs are those not in a special clique with these unqualified manager/supervisors. Lots of dirty tricks going on to make safe jobs of "pets", including promoting them to a higher grade to protect lower grade sections being laid off-even though they do no more work or are not even qualified. They are giving them raises and promotions while laying off other competent individuals who aren't in the " in crowd", kind of sickening to watch.

pros:
Getting a student job at UC Davis is a great way to get some professional experience, references, and spending money.
Networking is possible on these jobs.
cons:
Surprisingly little training was given. This led to a degree of work stagnation.
Raises are hard to come by, as are promotions. Essentially, to get these things, most of the time you have to take an entirely different position. At the student job where I worked, there was no apparent option to upgrade. Sometimes this is because of funding limitations.

review_title: Very relaxed work environment, but as with any higher ed institute, expect bureaucracy
pros: Working at UC Davis, I've found you get out what you put in — it can be a great place to learn new technologies and implement industry best practices if you take the initiative to make it happen. There are constantly new projects to work on and you can be sure these projects have an impact as UC Davis is often involved with cutting-edge research that improve quality of life around the world.
cons: It's incredibly difficult getting promotions or re-classed. Bureaucracy is rampant — projects often take much longer than you would expect anywhere else in the industry. Also, expect to be paid much less than elsewhere in the industry, although benefits are great especially if you have a family.

review_title: UCD is run like a business instead of a school
pros: The teaching assistant union (UAW 2865) got us a great contract, but it took several years to negotiate with the administration. The position includes much better health insurance than it used to, now that they are complying with the ACA. They used to have a $10K yearly cap.
cons: They keep increasing class sizes which lowers the quality of students' education. I have more students to teach, more papers to grade, and less time to give individual attention.

review_title: Overly political, overly bureaucratic, doesn't adapt well to change
pros: Fantastic benefits; good work-life balance; relatively stable job status
cons: IT is incredibly siloed. As a result, there's a lot of duplication of efforts and mismanagement of information. Each IT department is incredibly protective of its assets and power. Attempts to break down barriers between departments -- to share knowledge, technology, resources, etc. -- results in a lot of unnecessary pushback. Many IT employees here are overly complacent in their jobs and difficult to work with; they just don't feel inspired by their work!

review_title: Disorganized bureaucratic misplacement of research dollars
pros: Good benefits, decent pay, quick bike-ride to work (if you live in Davis), like to hire from within, friendly and pleasant research community
cons: Work overtime without receiving overtime pay, must rub elbows with everyone constantly or your scientific career will be hell here, so much red tape that nothing can ever get done, horrible hiring practices (prefer to hire an unqualified individual from the UCD pool than a qualified individual from an applicant pool). Positions are under-paid considering the responsibilities involved (in my case at least). It all boils down to poor leadership and spending preferences at the top of the chain.

review_title: One of the worst places I have worked
pros: generous sick leave and holidays
cons:
Hostile culture and extremely poor management
 The corporate culture at the UCD is very much a yes sir, how high do you want me to jump atmosphere. There is a great divide between the managers and the average employees, or as one of the top management put it "the lowly people". They seem to put people in management positions when they have no people skills and aren't able to communicate to other employees. Favortism is also a huge problem.UCD does not treat you with respect or professionalism. If you are looking for a position where you enjoy going to work everyday, where your opinion is valued, and your hard work is appreciated, avoid UCD If you have other options, take them.

job_title: Staff Research Associate II in Davis, CA
pros:
Opportunities to connect with bright minds from around the world (great for networking) 
Good work-life balance; paid holidays
Pay for research associates is comparable to or better than that of other employers in the area. 
Employer will pay for certain courses, certifications (opportunities for additional education)
cons:
Not much room for pay advancement.
There are no longer step increases so the only opportunities for salary increases are to be reclassed (i.e. SRA I to SRA II) or cost of living increases (for employees with unions)

review_title: Campus Recreation and Unions Student Employee
job_title: Student Assistant III in Davis, CA
pros: Very convenient and very flexible to fit the needs of students and their schedules. There are yearly banquets and student appreciation events. Employee discounts at the campus and off-campus book store on UC Davis items and apparel.
cons: Management is not well organized and does not seem highly motivated to work. Executives only seem to worry about their own salary needs. Very difficult or impossible to obtain a raise. No benefits, sick leave or vacation time.

review_title: Lots of freedom, nice town, OK pay
pros: A postdoc is a unique experience, it really depends on your supervisor and group. It has been nice at Davis. My group is very good and we have good facilities. I like the town. The campus is nice. There is swimming and a gym available not too far from my office, although I have to pay for these. Pay is tolerable for the town, Davis is not cheap though.
cons: Lots of freedom, almost too much sometimes. You need to keep on yourself to produce. It's your job. There can be a lot of bureaucracy in the university. Postdoc's do not accrue time in the Social Security system, which is something you may want to consider if you've been in Grad School for a while.

pros: Work/Life Balance, Retirement, Flexibility, Job Security, Medical Benefits.  Generally speaking, the culture is positive, supportive and family oriented.
cons: Small or Non Existent Development Teams, Management one or two layers above immediate supervisors have little to no software engineering experience or experience leading software development teams.  Executives at the most influential levels of leadership on campus are likewise of little help to a progressive Information Technology agenda.

pros: The school goes some distance to support graduate students and there are plenty of resources for improving your teaching, learning to deal with students, and protection against possibly overreaching professors and lecturers.
cons: A large portion of graduate students do not particularly care for the teaching aspect of their graduate career. The mathematics department has gotten rid of office hours and corrals undergraduates into a large general-purpose calculus room which, while undoubtedly more efficient for organization, leads to a lot of confusion and a great loss in personal connection with students.

review_title: Good benefits, ok salary for small town
pros: Being a university, UCD was not terribly stressful to work at. I did engineering consulting for some engineering profs. Co-workers were quite pleasant and the town itself is pretty nice, though many of the staff could not easily afford to live in the town and instead lived in nearby towns (Woodland, Winters, Dixon, West Sacramento). The town is super bike-friendly and has an awesome sense of community and identity. The campus is growing, adding shiny new buildings, and growing in stature and prestige year after year.
cons: Working with professors can often be a mixed bag. Some profs are quite nice and down-to-Earth, while others are, let's say, extremely confident in their awesomeness... and can be challenging (or downright unpleasant) to work with.

review_title: UC Davis, becoming an employer of choice
pros:
Excellent work-life balance
Good benefits
Salary expectations
Upward mobility
Good internal training opportunities
Diversity Awareness
Staff Appreciation
cons:
Staff morale issues
Union environment
Diversity in the workforce 
Salary limitations (merit)
Work-life-balance

pros: There is a great community of communications specialists who work in different areas across campus and who meet regularly during the school year to discuss different communications topics and methods of dissemination. The benefits are really nice. I have medical, dental, vision, and legal insurance for my spouse and I for under $200/month. Nice retirement match as well.
cons: The communications specialist role is fairly new and varies quite a bit from department to department based on the individual needs. The role could almost be called a communications generalist, as the role requires one to wear many hats (e.g. marketing, analytics, graphic design, content strategist, user experience design, web content manager, writer, copy editor, photographer, videographer, social media specialist, etc.), which can sometimes feel overwhelming.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Davis, CA
pros: Working here, you get to meet a number of very intelligent, very motivated people. You get to learn an entirely new skill set (in my case, anyway). The time is flexible and for a non-career position, the benefits and pay are very good. People are willing to patiently teach you a new skill or system without becoming irritated, and everyone is friendly and open.
cons: Some of the labs can be very difficult to work with, because when they do things improperly or without the required process, they tend to blame shoddy results on the administrative office, rather than on their own lack of attention to detail and procedure.

job_title: Academic Advising Coordinator in Davis, CA
pros: positive and healthy work environment, culturally sensitive, actively working to increase staff diversity, extensive professional development opportunities, forward thinking, inclusive, vibrant and beautiful grounds
cons: Davis is very expensive, commute is long due to traffic congestion, parking is atrocious and is expected to worsen with the continued development of large projects on both sides of the causeway. New public transit "Causeway Connection" has not been properly evaluated as viable commute option due to pandemic.

review_title: A place to grow professionally but unlikely to offer stability
pros:
You will be in a competitive environment where you will find many oportunities to network, pick up new skills, and in general do good research. 
I recommend establishing as many collaborations as you can, as is the most effective way to network.
Davis is a bit overpriced, but it's easy life style and small size contribute to good life-quality
cons: There are very few opportunities to find stability, regardless of experience or skills, the opportunities are so few that it's not only meritocratic and the extent of you connections  will be more important

review_title: Your experience here depends on your direct boss.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: Plenty of resources if you are resourceful, and there are people who are great at what they are doing.
cons: You have to be very proactive.  Oftentimes you will need to be very persistent to accomplish your tasks.  Double check not only your own work, but other's as well if you plan on relying on their information.

pros:
1. Pretty safe and quiet town. 
2. Nice people.
3. Nice place to work at.
4. Bicycle city, everyone rides bicycle
5. Academic environmental is OK, depend on Professor. But not as tight as other more popular universities.
6. Leisure life.
7. Close to Bay Area, bunch of opportunities to work after graduation.
cons:
1. Expensive and limited housing
2. No Walmart, or Costco in town.  Just Safeway, Savemart, whole foods, etc. expensive markets.
3. No near shopping center. Closest one is Arden Fair in Sacramento
4. Not much fun, if you are not a social animal.

review_title: Everything is on your shoulders,  but it's relatively simple work.
pros: Good hourly pay, creates a good connection with professors, relatively simple work. I graded for a professor that bought the group of graders pizza on a particularly difficult grading assignment that took several hours.
cons: Printing the hourly sheets, getting them signed by the professor, and dropping them off at the office is all on you -- can be tricky to remember and get done if you do not often interact with this professor and have to go back and forth to campus, especially during exams.

review_title: Best place to work. Great city to live in.
pros: For researchers, work hours are flexible. Postdoc union makes sure that the posdoc employees are well taken care of. Since it is not one of those crazy party schools, great for family. If you are one of those 'portlandia' type of persons, this is the town for you.
cons: Most of the apartment complexes have beautiful offices, but the apartment themselves are not so great. Very annoying leasing system. If you want to continue in your apartment next september, better sign the lease by Feb of the same year. Unnecessarily exorbitant house prices. But not to worry, neighboring towns with 10 min drive have same sized houses for half the price.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: small-town feel but close to larger cities.
cons: Part of a large university system (University of California)---and has developed alot of needless paperwork.  Professors aren't very good.  Not big enough name for the hastle.  Go to a smaller university with better professors and opportunities, or go to an actual ivy-league like Cornell.

review_title: Davis is an awesome place to live, work, and study.
pros: Davis has a small town feel but is inhabited by many smart, nice people and has many cultural attractions/benefits.
cons: Because life in Davis revolves so heavily around the university, sometimes it feels like there's not much else going on here.  But really, a top-notch university like Davis is a great place to work.

review_title: Great Agency to get job experience, great people, and student pay.
pros:
- pay (student pay): I started at 10.25 for student director position, which is great considering every other position in other units only get paid 8. 
- people: everyone gets along, is friendly and open minded. 
- environment: supervisor is great, gives you a lot of creative freedom and license. 
- conveniently located on campus
cons:
- some of the overhead student employees give bad opinions and conflict with each other a lot. 
- the schedule is a little too relaxed at times
- the  hours of the building close too early so its hard to finish up projects late at night.

review_title: Intellectual enrichment, with plenty of coffee shops
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: A great collection of intelligent thinkers that apply their brains to important problems. The atmosphere is charged with energy, and if you find a good collaborative and supportive group of people, you can make anything happen.
cons: Tenure should be revokable. Instead, professors can get away with actions that would have them fired at any other job or profession. The administration is overpaid but justify this by claiming that they must compete with the private sector for qualified candidates. And they like to pepper spray their students...

pros: Many of the departments offer a good work-life balance and there are goals to encourage more telecommuting. The health benefits, vacation, and sick leave are all wonderful.
cons: There are a lot of cliques and upward mobility can be difficult if you try to stay in the same department. Many times an open position already has a person identified prior to interviews. Reclassification and equity are only available for favorite employees. HR is often not a neutral ground, and will almost always side with management.

pros: It's a very good university with many top-quality researchers.  There is a very strong emphasis on biology of many sorts.  If your research is biology, there is a good chance you will find someone here doing work in your field.
cons: All the usual downsides of working for a university, i.e. you find your own funding, compensation isn't as good as industry, etc.

pros: UC Davis TAships give you a consistent stipend and tuition remission while you finish your graduate degree. I TAed for a lot of professors who were great to work with. Some TAships will give you teaching experience through leading discussion sections, and some will just be grading. The healthcare is actually pretty good!
cons: The stipend is barely enough to cover cost of living. There's little to no pedagogical training, so you learn how to teach over time on the job, which is tough for both you and your students. You are responsible for seeking out your own TAships (at least in my department), which is harder when you're starting out.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: Your experience will vary greatly between departments. I've been in the College of Engineering and had a very positive experience. Unlike undergraduates, grad students are pretty isolated from many of the controversial tuition decisions by the board of regents.
cons: Benefits of ASUCD membership are not extended to grad students (but we also don't pay the fees). These are pretty minor inconveniences, like having to pay a small fee for the bus or outdoor rec pool. Pay is not as great as many other schools, particularly given the cost of living.

pros: Great staff team, lots of training and job support, positive work environment, flexible student hours, lots of hours available. Much more interesting than most student jobs! Great starting point if you want to work at UCD after graduation.
cons: Can be taxing on schedule, especially if working with first-year programs (because of irregular hours). Pay hovers around minimum wage, and students can find better hourly pay on-campus (at SASC, for example).

pros: Great academic institution with all students seriously there to learn and grow. I give my highest regards to UCD and would recommend this school to anyone. Go here if you get in!
cons: The staff is spread pretty thin. The University of California system could always use more employees, professors are overworked and class sizes are to big. I think if the state of CA would allocate more to higher education in the state budget that would help completely.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Davis, CA
pros: This is a great school with all sorts of opportunities. The student community is diverse and friendly. The campus is beautiful and there is sunny weather for most of the year. TA duties are reasonable and grading is relatively low since there are no essays. Grading goes by more easily with groups of fellow TAs working with you.
cons: Winter weather is mostly rainy and makes biking harder for commuters. General chemistry safety meetings are very repetitive for experienced TAs.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: The pro of working at UC Davis is the general ambition of the University and its PI's to do better.  I work in the field of Cancer Research and the number of grant support will tell you that the scientists here are hungry for do more.
cons: Choosing a PI is difficult as not all mentors will prepare you to think like a scientist.  Many will just expect you to know or build your own path.  I don't mean this as a con but more so a warning to choose a PI you can work with who will make you the best you can be.

pros: Relaxed environment, lots of research variety, degree program is less stressful than most, Davis is a great town to live and hang out in
cons: High cost of living, degree program isn't as vigorous as most

review_title: Administration side review (legal) - good place to settle
pros: Working in the legal/compliance world, this is a good place to settle at. There is a extremely high level of job security, you get enough time off to raise a family, etc. Working at UC Davis has all the good parts of working in government (it is government) in that it has great job security and benefits (choice of pension of 7% matching a 403b) and lots of time off/flexibility for a more analytical/decision making position.
cons: The salary is near bottom market for compliance/legal. This is the main drawback, but if you can stomach the salary, it is otherwise a great place.

review_title: Great place to have on my newly building resume, not in my future though.
pros: Very hands on job that allowed me to work alongside other companies that I wouldn't have ever been able to. I easily could have made stronger connections with many CA and FED agencies.
cons: Too laid back for a career. Honestly made me think twice about what I wanted to work towards in life and I feel as if the people there had settled on something that I wouldn't be comfortable doing the same.

review_title: Decent university with some poor upper management in a annoying town.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: As a graduate researcher it is almost completely dependent on which professor your working for.  The small bit that is not professor dependent had its positives: the other graduate students a great and make a substantial community that can be very fun to participate in.
cons: As a graduate researcher it is almost completely dependent on which professor your working for.  The small bit that is not professor dependent had its negatives: the administration level employees do not seem to have a good grasp on what is they are being asked to do.

review_title: UC Davis great place to work with great benefits.
pros: The benefits and retirement pension are a definite plus.  It is also exciting to work on a college campus with a charged environment.  The best part of the job is definitely working with the students!
cons: Staff is not valued by upper management, they are definitely out of touch.  When you give a merit increase please make it an actual increase not just a small bump to try and cover the increase to our pension plans.

pros: The job had flexible hours. My supervisors, who were very nice and approachable, were willing to work around my schedule. Working for the university is like a good bridge between the real world and college; the atmosphere is relaxed and chill, but you still have to represent yourself as a professional and an academic. Also one of the highest paying jobs on campus.
cons: You might not get as many hours as you want, depending on your schedule and the demand for the subjects you teach. Also might be easy to put too much on your own plate; teaching multiple subjects require time for preparation and refreshing.

job_title: Student Assistant II in Davis, CA
pros: The hours are very flexible and I can work from home. The work is sort of mindless, which makes the low pay more bearable. It can also be a great way to build a relationship with a professor and get a letter of recommendation.
cons: The pay is not very good and I don't feel like I am gaining many marketable skills that will help build my resume. The work is sometimes very boring.

review_title: technically not a university employee, but a contractor.
pros: My job is flexible.  Pay is decent.  Nice town to live in.  I'm challenged to learn new skills.  I enjoy my work.
cons: Not all bosses are created equal.  As a contractor, I receive no benefits, and must find my own health insurance.  However, my pay is adjusted for such.  A lot of the work is done in the office.

pros: Great hours, it's research so a lot depends on your PI. If you can consistently get results from your experiments and keep your PI happy, then it's a low-stress job.
cons: If your PI is bad, then Godspeed. You need to consistently produce results, or else you're out of a job. Sometimes the projects you get go nowhere, and you have to start over from scratch. There's not a lot of room for job advancement without an advanced degree

review_title: Positive experience, but could be better
pros: Autonomy, flexibility, meaningful and interesting work. Great collaborative environment, access to core resources. Depending on your PI, lab environment and project, overall this is a great place to work.
cons: While pay has increased during my time here and the union is effective, it still does not meet what is actually demanded of us- this is not necessarily the UC's fault as they follow NIH guidelines. Parking is horrible, administrative support (at least for our department) is lacking. Sacramento campus feels very removed from main UC (i.e. Access to full complement of core facilities, seminars and workshops are difficult to attend, etc).

pros: They're very lenient about work hours. They know school will come first to students. They don't mind working with you until you get the hang of things.
cons: You will be asked to do the same task over and over. Additionally, planning isn't the greatest, especially for minor projects and you may actually be asked to do something and then promptly un do it. It's kinda ridiculous.

review_title: Great place to work after graduating
pros: It mostly depends on the lab you're working with.  It's really difficult to give a general description of working at the University since there are so many positions and I've worked in 4 different labs that all have different pros and cons.  The health care benefits are great, and generally there's a lot of flexibility.
cons: I don't think the University is as supportive of it's research labs as it should be.  It sometimes hinders research more than helping it.  The benefits for staff have been steadily decreasing as money becomes more scarce so it's becoming less worth the small salary.

review_title: Great for technology and innovation, could do better with managing people.
pros: Excellent environment for working with technology and innovating new lighting solutions. Lots of great projects with practical focus on delivering useful work. Great work/life balance.
cons: Scientists and engineers do not always make the best managers. Soft skills in management could have be improved. University R&D job so pay was well below market value. Political skills required to advance.

pros: Love the variety of my work and serving the research community
cons: They do not deal with the problemtic bullying management. You can go up the ladder to HR and senior management but they close their eyes to problems. You have to leave because nothing will change, guaranteed. The only way to get ahead is by job jumping. Do not even think about hard work equaling upward mobility. It will not happen.

review_title: Good Job, if you don't mind social justice
pros:
Very Flexible
Provides Housing + Meal Plan for less than 20hrs of work a week
Small stipends for returning RAs
Priority Registration for classes
Gain experience in a wide variety of tasks
Lots of responsibility - good resume builder
No need to worry about hours, less impact on FAFSA and taxes
cons:
Very restrictive with respect to internships, must be approved for outside committments
Must believe in social justice and practice political correctness
Easy to lose motivation
You live where you work - difficult to get away from job, highly visible in community
Must spend one month of summer in training
Must drop everything to deal with resident situations at times

review_title: Great place to work but with the usual academic bureaucracy
pros: The UC Davis campus is beautiful. I was actually based on the medical campus in Sacramento which suited me better as I was closer to the larger city of Sac, rather than being stuck in the college town of Davis. Davis however is great for families.
cons: If you are split between the two campuses it can be a pain to have to keep crossing the causeway. Traffic can suck big time. There are not enough shuttles between the campuses (one an hour) so for someone like me who had no car, this was quite inconvenient.

review_title: Graduate student researchers offers new opportunities to excel, however, be prepared to deal with troublesome issues.
pros: Ability to work with academic leaders in your fields. Many of your peers are motivated individuals driven to be the best. The technical support staff are excellent, although the office members are sometimes slow on the uptake.
cons:
Work environment is lacking in basic amenities.
Dispersion of groups hinders collaboration.
A lack of distinct management and department goals hinders future work.

pros: The benefits and pay are good, the researchers I worked with were fantastic, and the proximity to Sacramento was super useful in my particular field. Also, the campus is beautiful and Davis is a nice town to live and work in if you can afford it.
cons: The work environment isn't always inspiring. Some folks who work for the university are kind of coasting since the advancement opportunities are not obvious. You really need to push to make your experience the best it can be.

review_title: A good job for a year
pros: Overall, good leadership experience. The compensation is really great, especially compared to any other job you can get on campus. There are good opportunities to advance as a returning RA or SRA.
cons: For me, the toughest part was taking on the "RA personality" that Student Housing expects. I felt a bit like I had to hide parts of who I was to avoid attracting negative attention due to their intense love of "diversity".

review_title: It is a very cooperative and friendly environment that is ideal for pursuing graduate school.
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Davis, CA
pros: Th education and interdisciplinary environment is beneficial to graduate schools who are interested in exploring many fields of study.
cons: Pursuing a PhD is difficult at times because one has to take the initiative to seek out help rather than being offered help.

pros: Benefits (including beyond health), job security, pension (if you were hired before 2013), work environment, working for a cause, pride in the mission of the University.
cons: Heavy on policy and procedure (bureaucracy), answering to tax payers and being highly risk-averse and transparent can sometimes create situations that are impossible and decision-making is debilitated, projects and efficiency suffer for it. Also, at higher levels, often many people are involved in a decision and often eventually no one will make that decision due to the previously mentioned issues, then perhaps a project that has been worked on for a year will stall or die altogether. In attempts to save money often 'free' programs are used that don't serve our needs or don't work well or can't be updated. (This has actually gotten better) Often UC's attempt to save money on programs, or to find the best thing everyone can agree on, costs more money than just getting what we need that would work for us. Tax payers and donors never want to pay for salaries, you will make less here than doing the same job anywhere else, but the benefits often make up for that, do your research.  There are basically no 'promotions' to move up (often even in your same department) you have to apply and interview. And  you have to pay for parking at most of the place you'll work on campus or in Davis.

job_title: Staff Research Associate II in Davis, CA
pros:
- co workers are overall great to work with
- great benefits
- starting pay is great
cons:
- if you have a bad pi it can be miserable
- funding for a lab is dependent on grants your pi receives and if your pi doesn't receive any you can get laid off/lab shut down
- slow increase with the university constantly dragging their feet when it comes to retaining employee benefits and increases in pay
- very difficult for upward mobility
- too many politics involved
- depending on your pi you may be overworked

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: Davis is a beautiful city. It is very safe. It has very good weather. It is very close to big metropolis. One can get a decent degree
cons: For getting a degree, Professors clearly exploit the life of students and makes it that does not worth to get a degree. Most of the porfessor has the attitude of you will get a degree and I will make you pay for it towards graduate students.

review_title: Excellent experience, especially for working students
pros: Flexible schedual, decent pay, amazing co-workers and management that are always will to teach you. Overall a very fun atmosphere, and the work was rewarding to know you are contributing to the greater scientific community
cons: You probably wont ever get rich working in the field. It has does have a general cap and at times the work load can suddenly raise for a week or two depending on other external factors beyond the managers control

pros:
Friendly and energetic work environment, 
good benefits for all workers, 
laid back work culture, 
knowledgeable coworkers, 
amazing learning opportunities for everyone interested, 
Fantastic environment for research.
cons:
Salary for postdocs are low compared to administrators and faculty.
Davis town very small and overpriced for the facilities it offers.
Have to travel to Sacramento or San Francisco to get big city experience.

pros: Great environment for professional development. The workplace environment is very friendly and collaborative, although as with all academic positions it can be highly stressful at times. The benefits for postdoctoral fellows at ucd are exemplary.
cons: The pay is not great by California standards. The university should adjust for cost of living, if possible!

review_title: Job depends STRONGLY on who your lab head is
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros:
Great healthcare thanks to Graduate Student union bargaining
Beautiful location
My lab head gives mu *lots* of flexibility as long as I get things done, which works very well for me.
cons:
Budget cuts are demoralizing.
To some degree, there's a climate of pooh-poohing new ideas just because they're new, and would require a change.

review_title: UC Davis has a new vision to expand its engage as an enterprise for innovation.
pros: New research and innovation help to create a culture that is always changing and evolving.  With new scientists in leadership roles and new initiatives, there is always something to learn to expand your professional development.
cons: The administrative structure does not keep up with the advances in scholarship, research and innovation.  With many new leadership positions on campus, there is a learning curve before important strategic leadership decisions can be made.

review_title: Great training and experience if you work in the right lab, no room to grow
pros: The labs are really laid back and people are always willing to share their talents and help you troubleshoot. It is a great environment where like-minded thinkers can get together to share ideas and a place to make friends that are around the same age group. If the PI of the lab is passionate about the lab, you will receive great training and will be given good opportunities. Those variety of work experiences can be carried on into the next  job. It is great to have a variety of techniques under your belt, whereas other jobs will just train you to do ONE thing, and one thing only.  PTO is 3 weeks for someone who is just starting at a junior position, and the medical benefits are great--I have not paid out of pocket for general medical needs.
cons:
There is no growth, if you don't have a PhD, you won't be able to go anywhere with your career at a university. The only research you can do is be a technician, always doing the repetitive jobs that the PI or graduate students don't have time for. For how many hats a technician wears-- lab management, hiring lab assistants, doing their own projects, picking up on other people's projects, etc., the compensation is very low. Even if the technician holds a master's degree, they get paid the same amount as someone who just received their Bachelor's two months ago.
Safety is a big issue and the university labs seems to be very relaxed about it.
 Even though Environmental Health & Safety implements rules and checks the labs yearly, but it is not enough. People eat and drink in the lab, wear opened toe-ed shoes, etc. Safety precautions in some labs often do not exist when handling dangerous or volatile chemicals, and careful chemical disposal measures do not exist. The use of large and expensive equipment have lack of training and they expect you to know how to use it off the bat (ie. large autoclaves, centrifuges, biological safety cabinets).

pros: good time for work, not high work load, students always be easy to get along and also the professor. Sometimes get into trouble when groups maybe lazy. Great at whole
cons: small time taken, but had to explain much to students in long office hours. labs numbers limited so have to be careful not to be conflict. Need to know code in advance

pros:
Great student workplace, neatly organized and tailor to student employees. You get a
Free cap and gown at graduation! Also free ARC membership during the summer!
Lots of opportunity and upward mobility for students, easy to become a student manager, every year they hire after graduation.
cons: Tasks can become repetitive and the work environment can become monotonous. Workers and management can get caught up in trash talking.

review_title:
Tripping hazard removal replacement concrete,
Brick, asphalt   Heavy equipment operator 
Concrete , brick, stone mason
pros:
Great place to work good pay and benefits 
Vacation and sick leave.   The scenery is the best
From the arboretum to all the students just priceless
cons: Dealing with all the bull from people that have jobs above you getting a lot more pay that are stupid they had to of known somebody to have  hired   They oil all the squeeky wheels.  Hire people without interviews move to different departments.   HR lies to there employees

pros: My department (under Campus Recreations) is fortunately very flexible and understanding in regards to work-school balance. Can commit as much time to the job as you see fit.
cons: Your experience is very dependent on the program you work for.  Our program is very overstaffed, making it difficult to get hours. Some students are only able to get 5-6 hours a week.

review_title: Great school, but relatively low stipend given the high living expenses
pros:
First of all, it is one of UC's. Good reputation at both national and international levels.
Location is also great. Less than 2 hours to Bay area, and 30 minutes to the state capital.
People are friendly and tolerant in general.
cons: High living expenses. It is true that Davis is cheaper than most of places in Bay area, but life is kind of tough for low-level employees.

review_title: Pretty good, could be much better
pros: Good diversity, good benefits, supporting students and higher educational opportunities for all (world-wide). I like working with smart people. Most do the best they can.  Very few (less than half of 1%) take advantage. There is some work/life balance.
cons: it is a giant bureaucracy. The politics are non-stop and so tricky to navigate. You work hard, but no raises for staff. Most managers are poorly trained and don't know how to motivate staff. Very little chance to advance in your dept. You usually have to go to another dept. for promotions.

review_title: Campus Recreation and Unions, Aquatics: Lifeguard
pros: Friendly staff and flexible hours, work is generally easy except when Rec Pool is open during Spring and Summer.  Getting to know professors that are regulars to lap swim is a great way to make connections.
cons: Shifts are short and spread out, good for working around classes but it often inconvenient considering the time and effort required to attend a 1-2 hours shift possible multiple times a day.

pros: Very flexible depending on the Professor that is the instructor for the course, I have TAed lab and regular classes, just don't let the professor work you over the necessary hours.
cons: Working with students and/or professors that are utterly dense.  Be aware of what the professor says in class, by even going to class to ensure that you are both on the right page.

pros: For student assistants, the department on campus jobs provide a flexible schedule, fun co-workers and a good learning experience for the real world. It was nice to be able to cater the work schedule around classes every quarter and stay on campus.
cons: The pay isn't anything grand and sometimes you get stuck with doing something no one else wants to do, but in the end, you're a student and it's a paying job. Sometimes hard to schedule out during midterms and finals weeks.

pros: 'A' parking permit, awesome and laid back campus, CoHo food can be boring but at least not bad and cheap, bike-friendly town, great work-life balance, pretty good benefits.
cons: Since it is an university, a good number of positions are grant-based like I was and compensation was pretty low. And I was laid off because of it so keep a foot out the door just in case. Have to pay for services like Unitrans or ARC membership. Sometimes make me miss the good 'ol days of being a student at UCD.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Davis, CA
pros: As a graduate student employed as a teaching assistan, I enjoy riding my bike to and from campus and the perks of working at a university - sitting in on interesting lectures during my lunch break, enjoying the student union and the student recreation area.
cons: The administration of my department is extremely slow and I feel like I have to double check constantly that things my lab need from them do get done in time. Not the fault of individual employees though - they have been really understaffed for over a year now.

pros: Great benefits, great coworkers, contributing to greater research and education mission of UC System
cons: Transition to Shared Services for HR, Purcahsing, and Payroll has been tough - it's hard to get things done in a timely manner, and turnover and standards changes have made things a bit hard to follow chain of command. Very little investment in employee training at the departmental level - no budget for specific skills training, research, tradeshows, etc.

review_title: Very little recognition for your efforts
pros: The Center for Excellence in Teaching and Learning offers great workshops and resources to help you become a better instructor and teaching assistant. Professors will generally be understanding of your schedule.
cons: There will be almost no recognition of your ability or your efforts as an instructor. You will work shoulder to shoulder with people who do not care a lick about teaching and you will be paid the same no matter your ability or results.

review_title: Good job while a graduate student
pros: Flexible schedule; decent pay for only 20 hrs/wk. Allows plenty of time for your graduate studies. There is a fair amount of ebb and flow in the workload - some weeks you'll work more than 20 hrs/wk, others you'll work far less - but most weeks you're apt to put in far less than 20 hrs.
cons: Experience will vary depending on faculty you're TAing for

pros: Pay is quite low compared to private sector but benefits and very stable employment make up for that. Very relaxed work environment maybe even a little to relaxed sometimes.
cons: A lot of entitlement and complacency from the 10+ year employees. It depends on your department but if your a shift worker your department may not ever rotate shifts so the one your hired for is the one your stuck on. Not a ton of opportunities to advance due to many 20+ year employees staying in the same positions.

job_title: Member Services Attendant in Davis, CA
pros: The culture is nice as it is mostly students, so as a student you will build a lot of connections. It is also conveinient because it is on campus and the management knows so it is worked into your schdule. Good place for your first job, as they mainly look for behavioral/cultural fit.
cons: It sucks to have an opening or closing shift as it can be very early, or very late. Sometimes you will get stuck with these shifts, but that's not too bad, because almost every employee has.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Davis, CA
pros: Covers student fees. Opportunity to work while working on thesis project. Wide variety of projects in many different departments. Top class research facilities.
cons: Funding can be limited. Faculty members are not trained well (or perhaps at all) in managing students- some are great, but others are not. As a student, you cannot officially work more than 20 hours/week even though most weeks come out to 50-60hours.

job_title: Health and Safety Specialist in Davis, CA
pros: The company as a whole really values work life balance. They encourage employees to participate in wellness programs to really help all employees continue to be healthy. Managers honor the set 8 hour work day and really encourage employees to grow within the system.
cons: Parking! Not enough parking and way too expensive. Since it is a state/ federally funded organization, salary is not as competitive.

job_title: Student Affairs Officer II in Davis, CA
pros:
Wonderful colleagues
Ability to serve students and make positive impact
Interesting work with lots of variety
cons:
Lay-offs
Expected to do more with less and having to do work of those layed-off
Depressing budgetary times

job_title: Engineering Tour Guide in Davis, CA
pros: Working with fellow tour guides from all over campus. The hours were flexible as long as you contribute a minimum amount a week. A bit of overlap on normal tours except for mandatory dates like Picnic Day or Visitor Days.
