cons: None. Everyone from new hires to administrators seem extremely happy to be there to work to help the visitors to attend the University.

job_title: Student Assistant II in Davis, CA
pros: Working for UC Davis was a stable job and was a convenient location. Most employers are considerate of the students' need to put schoolwork first.
cons: It was difficult to advance in position and the jobs, in general, do not pay very much above minimum wage. The tasks can also be extremely tedious. They jobs are also really difficult to get because there are a lot of students vying for the same position, and often jobs are only for students who qualify for work study.

pros: Friendly faculty, flexible hours, good work-life balance
cons: Sometimes gets busy and stressful, sometimes TAs get thrown into new situations without much guidance

review_title: Casual job with flexible hours in a fun, working environment
pros: The student coordinator is very accommodating when it comes to shift changes. The student workers and full-time workers are very friendly. There are many divisions in which you can work once you are employed which include events, parking enforcement, bike enforcement, Northgate and Southgate.
cons: You have to go in person to sign up for events rather than signing up online. A lot of times, by the time you get there to sign up, almost every good shift is filled.

pros: Extensive biking paths (bike capital of the country),  pleasant family-friendly atmosphere,  strong community culture, excellence in food and agriculture, relatively quiet campus
cons: Somewhat laid back and complacent staff (may be anecdotal), very hot in the summer, there is a huge amount of surrounding land but limited in opportunity if you want to build/own your own home (expensive!!), not much nightlife

review_title: UC Davis may be a good place to go to school, but it is not such a great place to work.
pros: Very good benefits, access to facilities if you get in with the right department
cons: Very nepotistic, temp jobs often being disguised/touted as full-time

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: They have great access to resources and free classes on any subject you want.  Also, Davis has a great small town feel, but is close to the Sacramento and San Francisco, as well as Tahoe where we go snowboarding every weekend.
cons: UC system doesn't pay as high as other universities with respect to cost of living.  However, in the long run, because we'll have access to better jobs, this is a short-term problem.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: Very dynamic research environment. Lots of seminars to attend. Lots of help you can get from different school offices. I especially like the Internship and Career center which is very helpful in job search.
cons: The faculties are more focused on their research than teaching. It is hard to find classes in you field of interest.

job_title: Student Assistant/Undergraduate Researcher in Davis, CA
pros:
-Learned a lot of new techniques
-Helps the undergrad gain experience for future experiences
-Awesome supervisor willing to teach and invest time in undergrads
cons:
-I heard from other people's experiences that you might end up doing dishes--to avoid doing only this for your undergrad career (if it's not in the job description), take initiative to learn from lab mates or your PI; get involved and try to start your own project
-it can be intimidating going in as a student knowing nothing, but everyone needs to start somewhere

pros:
You get to work with your fellow aggies and some truly exceptional staff. 

Possibilities for management experience and hiring experience

Low oversight with high responsibility

Easy to get from your job to your classes and visa versa. Extremely flexible hours

Possibility for advancement and connections to staff for lateral movement into a career position (if interested and exceptional)

Potential to work closely with executive staff on a regular basis.
cons:
Low pay

Often required heavy lifting

pros: Great learning experience. Excellent opportunities to network and bond with both residents and other RAs. You will quickly learn time management skills and become good at communicating with a broad range of people.
cons: It is a 24-hour job. There can be a lot of stress when you work where you live because you do not have a break from your position.

pros: Co workers were very supportive and always had time to work with me. Hours were very flexible, a must for any student working on campus.
cons: The workload was a bit uneven, and it felt like we had long periods of nothing to do followed by short periods of heavy work. Management was unsure about what duties we had.

review_title: Junior Specialist as Electrical and Mechanical Engineer en University of California, Davis
pros: Working in order to save energy and water is nowadays a challenge allowing to me to develop some of my previous experience in the engineering environment.
cons: This job is not a full time job and without a continuous flow of work load, so it is not providing a enough professional stability

pros: Working at an institution like this you know you will have a job indefinitely if you want. However, this job for me was just a stop gap really.
cons: There is not that much room for upward mobility, at least in the department that I am working for. I did not have that much responsibility.

job_title: Clinical Lab Scientist in Davis, CA
pros: Great staff.  Good pay.  Good benefits.
cons: Failure to classify employee according to university job specifications.  Top heavy administrators who care nothing for the staff employee. Staff not considered an asset.  Employees fear job loss and thus will not report law violations which occur way too often, especially at the administration level.  Supervisors and higher staff can do not wrong.  ADA and EEOC violations occur too often.  Cover-ups rampant at any management level.

review_title: Laid back atmosphere, yet a lot of red tape
pros: California is beautiful. UCD is small enough that people from various departments get to know each other. Davis is small, fairly safe and friendly. A 40-hour week seems to be pretty standard, and lots of holidays.
cons: There is an absurd amount of red tape compared to other places (in other states). People are very laid back, which can be a problem if you need something done in a hurry. Pay is average, but cost of living is high.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: Nice environment for a grad student researcher, good work-life balance and good atmosphere in the lab (at least in my lab). Professors are happy to offer help.
cons: Limited funding for big scientific instrument (which are really in need) and also lack of research funding for many PIs. Though they did not cut the grad researcher stipend but it's really bad to worry about money when doing research.

pros: It is a really good company to work for when you are younger. you can get a lot of experience in a kitchen and learn a lot from the chefs. They have good benefits, and you get a lot of time off because they are closed during a lot of holidays (Christmas, thanksgiving, summer break)
cons: It's more of a production line, and less of a cooking job. There is also a lot of favoritism from the management and the favorites get better shift selections.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: Flexible work schedule. My project had interesting research, so the work itself was rewarding. My colleagues were collaborative and respectful of one another. Fee remission is a fantastic benefit.
cons: Employment was based on grant (soft) money, so employment lasts as long as the grant lasts. Navigating university bureaucracy for purchases/reimbursements was time consuming.

review_title: Was a very safe/stable job, state budget cuts are making it more unstable.
pros:
* Good benefits 
* Pension
* Good work/life balance
cons:
* Recent changes to pension are worrying for young employees far from retirement.  (Will it be there when I retire?)
* Salary is not on par with private sector - but that is to be expected from a public University.
* Budget cuts are resulting in layoffs and general downsizing.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Davis, CA
pros: I've been a GRA for over a year now and really love it.  While research and work is important, academics are given top priority and I always get time off for finals or big assignments.
cons: Research deadlines can be nebulous at best.  It's really hard for someone who's worked in private industry. Also, often the right hand doesn't know what the left hand is doing.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Davis, CA
pros: UC Davis is a fun place to work. The school has access to good benefits for full time employees and an exciting atmosphere to work in. The town of Davis is very family friendly and has great local schools.
cons: The UC system does not pay as high as other universities and negotiating your salary is not straightforward, especially if you are doing research. Unfortunately, for graduate students who have families, it is financially difficult to afford healthcare and a basic lifestyle.

pros: We have postdoc union, which handles a lot of things for you, like pay-scale negotiation, health insurance, etc. UC postdocs health insurance is super good IMO.
cons: I don't really have complaints about working here. Except that the salary is not as optimal as working in the industry, but I guess that's an universal issue for postdocs.

review_title: Not Recommended for Non-Senate Faculty Academics
pros: You'll have rewarding opportunities to teach, publish, and conduct research.
cons: The employment model was designed for staff and faculty, and pretty much everyone else is treated like a temp. Don't bother trying to make a career of it there.

review_title: Perfect part-time job for a full-time student; very flexible and good pay compared to other campus jobs.
job_title: Student Assistant III in Davis, CA
pros: Flexible based on class schedule. One of the highest paying jobs at the Bookstore. Sales and customer service experience that is applicable to other real-life situations.
cons: Requires more effort than the standard cashier job at the Bookstore. Usually drawbacks of a customer service oriented sales job.

review_title: Goal-oriented, good management, and friendly people
job_title: Student Assistant III in Davis, CA
pros: As a student, I was given clear instructions for my assignments. Supervisors are open and available for questions and give their employees room to grow and learn different skills. Since I was a part-time employee, my hours were flexible and they were willing to fit my needs. People are friendly and helpful.
cons: More training for their full-time employees for specific projects. Allow more opportunities to take on more challenging projects.

pros:
- Flexible hours
- Good pay
- Hands on experience
- Ability to take on individual projects
- Relaxed work environment
- Develops a good relationship with professors
- Counts towards class credits/requirements
cons:
- Narrow spectrum of research
- No room for lateral or vertical movement
- Sometimes tedious work
- Labs are sometimes underfunded

review_title: Great benefits, low pay, steady employment, unexciting.
pros: Stable employment, great benefits, lots of time off, collegial environment. My job was low pressure but I got to do lots of interesting things.
cons: Almost impossible to fire low performers. Lots of abuse from people who work the system. Difficult to move up once you're at the top of your pay scale.

review_title: Do not go here if you do not want to get a masters of PhD
pros: Has benefits and other staff resources which are nice.
cons: If you do not have a masters or PhD (and do not really want to get one), then this place does not have many options for you since most of the higher level positions require advanced education.

job_title: Program Representative I in Davis, CA
pros:
Benefits are amazing
In my line of work, salary is okay
Work-life balance is amazing - my supervisor is very flexible and I am able to honor my family commitments.  
Feel like I am doing some important work
cons:
Training can be lacking and I don't see a whole lot of room for advancement in my field unless I go get a PhD and become an academic.  
Often, computer systems and other technological areas are very outdated.

pros: I am working as a post-doctoral researcher. So, my experience should be considered only for my department as there is not much interaction with rest of the University and students. I had a good time working in the lab.
cons: There is no interaction of the post-doctoral researchers with the students or rest of the department. This makes them detached from the University in general. This is more so for foreigners who were not connected to UCD for their previous education.

review_title: Being a tour guide for UC Davis was AWESOME!!!
pros:
You get to show why you love this beautiful campus and this fantastic school. 
Being the first impression for potential students.
You get to test you new comedy material on a new audience every time you have a tour to give.
LEARNING TO WALK BACKWARDS!!!
cons:
Memorizing the 16 page script. It's tough, but doable.
Learning the tour route through campus. Again, it's tough, but very doable.

job_title: Staff Research Associate I in Davis, CA
pros: Decent Benefits, Safe and Interesting Place to work
cons:
Management is often bloated with bureaucracy as well as inefficiency (like just about anywhere else, it would seem)

No merit based incentives.

pros: Lots of nice people, great location (especially for a family), good benefits, pretty intellectual community, lots of diversity, healthy living (super bike-friendly town)
cons: Can be a bit boring, perhaps a bit under-rated, probably not great pay unless you're a high-level administrator, academic mindset can be stifling sometimes

review_title: Intellectually stimulating environment that fosters personal and professional growth
pros: As a lab member, you will be both challenged constantly and fully supported in your  development, both as a person and as a team member. If you can rise to this challenge, your experience at the Saron Lab will prove invaluable in future endeavors.
cons: Lab meetings can at times be overly lengthy due to differing opinions and inefficient implementation of overarching project management structure (though this was getting better when I left).

pros: Dynamic and interesting work. Work in an academic environment with intellectually stimulating workshops, symposia, etc. Being a part of research that is larger than yourself is exciting.
cons: Management fails to recognize quality employees and often, when positions are cut, workloads increase for everyone. Compensation is never addressed when workload is increased, and you can't negotiate your own contract if you are in a unionized position.

pros: Nice staff and good hours. I worked in a vet med lab and very much enjoyed my time. Would recommend meeting with Prof before hand.
cons: Really dependent on what lab you work in.  Can be kind of boring depending on what knowledge you have. But, for just a starting position it has its benefits.

pros: As a student, campus employers work around your class schedule. There are also lots of student employment opportunities at UCD in many different fields and specialties.
cons: Most student positions offer little opportunity for advancement. After graduation, you have only one additional term before you become ineligible to continue working in a student position.

review_title: Good place to be, but can be better.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: University of California Davis is located in California’s Central Valley, a rather rural area that prompted the nickname “University Farm School.” However, UC Davis is now a recognized as a major research institution. Over 50% of their students work on some form of research project during their studies at Davis. Smart people, great campus.
cons: It's a small town. Most people are in their 20s and partying.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Very nice co-workers, flexible schedules, good working environment. Really liked how everyone was really friendly, and you learn a lot from the staff.
cons: Depending on the department you work for on campus, sometimes there isn't always work to do so it can get a little boring. Otherwise UC Davis is a good place for students to work part-time.

review_title: UC Davis is a great place to work
pros: Interesting work. Excellent benefits. Wonderful town to live in. Mostly very good co workers
cons: low pay, relatively speaking. There is an idea that one can hire a student to do pretty much anything which leads to trouble sometimes because either the student didn't really know what they were doing or they did fine but obviously can't stick around to do maintenance. Still, it's good for the students!

review_title: Tool to succeed are available iif you look for the opportunities
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: Good collaboration between departments and other collaborating campuses. Campus offers many programs to get you ready for jobs after graduation.
cons: There seems to be some tension with each of the departments, which sometimes slows down process and prevents further growth.

job_title: First Year Experience Peer Advisor in Davis, CA
pros: Flexible work environment with other students.  They gave us the ability to do outside tasks (homework) when things were slow.  Flexible hours.  Easy to get shifts covered.
cons: Staff meetings were often held even when no information needed to be covered.  Staff was often burnt out from working the entire summer orientation.

pros: Covered tuition, medical, and decent living stipend. Great experience for teaching in the future. Teaching assistants are protected under a union.
cons: Experience varies by professor. Although technically limited to 20 hours a week, many times you have to work up to 30+ just to finish grading midterms or finals.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Davis, CA
pros: Nice location. Inclusion into the University of California collective bargaining agreement ensures that postdocs get competitive salary and benefits such as healthcare taken care of
cons: Many people are only friendly on the surface. As Davis is a small town, the two most prevalent past-times for people here is to drink and to gossip.

pros: The teaching, research, and service mission is very compelling. Managers and staff have access to excellent training. Many units have high quality staff and low turnover. Very good health and retirement benefits. Both the Davis and Sacramento campuses provide many types of jobs. Within 2 hours of San Francisco, the wine country, and Lake Tahoe.
cons: Some managers do not take advantage of the excellent training, though fortunately all new managers have some required training.

review_title: A beautiful, bicycle-friendly campus with friendly co-workers and sensible leadership
pros: Friendly coworkers, high-achieving students, charismatic chancellor in Gary May, strong sense of community and social uplift of a land-grand university that is committed to improving the lives of its students and the people of California.
cons: High expectations for employees, the isolation of necessary covid-19 lockdowns (Fall 2020). Davis is an expensive place to live. Lack of live music venues (outside the Mondavi Center).

pros: Great place to work for. Unitrans supported me through my college career. There is always enough work, the people are great, and the atmosphere is fun.
cons: Sometimes you have to work at time when you don't want to, but that's with every job. Management can sometimes be jaded but most of the time is great!

review_title: Okay but could have been better
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Davis, CA
pros: Lots of potential freedom in terms of time (vacations) if you plan things right.
cons: The graduate student researcher pay scale is based on seemingly arbitrarily set levels, so a graduate student in one group/department can get paid way more than a graduate student in another.

review_title: Great working environment; too many positions are term-limited or seasonal.
pros:
Helpful and supportive colleagues and management.
Health, vision, and dental benefit options are excellent.
There are lots of resources available to employees.
The university has a progressive culture.
cons: Few career-track or fully funded positions in the sciences.  Most positions are limited-term, seasonal, or subject to fluctuations in funding.

pros: It's really bad that davis is located a little far from where the companies are. So, you don't get the chance to meet with the poeple from companies and build your network.
cons: It is still possible to commute to bay area. So, if you have some poeple that you can stay with, you can go there occasionally and try to meet poeple from the companies.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Davis, CA
pros: Excellent campus, good benefits for graduate students, reasonable stipend, ample opportunities for internal funding as well as support for securing external fellowships. Highly collaborative environment (at least in my department)
cons: Little departmental oversight of PI mentorship of graduate students, qualifying exams are fairly inconsistent in level of rigor and confrontation by faculty.

review_title: Great learning experience, not what I want to do as a career though.
pros: My adviser was really helpful and taught me all that I needed to know. I was able to fit my hours around my life, as long as I got what I needed done.
cons: Compensation and benefits were extremely low, if not nonexistent. I had to follow research run by adviser, and was not able to come up with my own research.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Davis, CA
pros: Exposed to many aspects of the administrative side of the campus. Learned how to use excel extensively. Supervisors are very patient in explaining tasks. They are also mindful of my school schedule, allowing me to be flexible with my hours. Overall very chill work place.
cons:
I sometimes have nothing to do, so I just study at my desk.
Not challenged enough on tasks, though its not an internship, I would still like to learn more.

pros: Awesome campus, pretty chill, hot, and warm weather. People over here are really kind and friendly. UC Davis has one of the best research campuses in US. It is close to National Labs and other top 5 universities. Good for collaboration
cons: It is far from Bay Area and Sacramento. During holidays it is pretty empty. Summer is boring and you have to get out very often to have good time. Otherwise everything is satisfactory.

review_title: Good for students looking for jobs
pros:
Working along fellow student
This is a good first job with room to move up the chain of command as well as provides customer service skills and gives the opportunity for leadership.
cons: At times schedules like late night can be tough for a student, management at the time was not there for students and overworked staff when others would call out. At times was understaffed.

pros: You can have a flexible schedule, you get to work with some interesting people, you can get a good education and work experience
cons: This is not a great time to be in academia.   There is a lot of 'dead wood' especially in admin.

job_title: Student Assistant IV in Davis, CA
pros: The work experience I gained as part of a research center was perfect for someone early in their career, and I would definitely suggest working there.
cons: The pay left something to be desired -- I was an undergrad Student Assistant, and at the time, that mean I got paid $8.50 an hour. The second summer I worked there, my skills had increased that to $9.25, so I suppose there was an improvement.

review_title: I enjoyed my time working for the Fitness and Wellness Department, the staff was extremely friendly!
pros:
-Friendly staff
-Flexible Hours
- The facilities are absolutely outstanding and their gym has to be one of the best in the county
Fantastic working environment and conditions
cons:
-Below industry standard pay.
-Cap of 20 hours for students

review_title: Great Way to Pay for College
pros: This was a great way to pay for my Master's program. Not only was tuition fully taken care of, but I was paid an additional hourly rate. Also, this position is just 10 hours per week which is very reasonable.
cons: Nothing. Just be aware that you will have additional work for this position at the end of the quarter in addition to extra work for your own classes: time management!

pros:
Coworkers are friendly
Free food if working the closing shift
Easy to get as a first job for a student
cons:
Don't always follow your restricted hours (could conflict with classes etc)
Student Managers were sometimes rude (to the point it made me leave)
Career Managers look down on you from other departments

job_title: Business Development Student Manager in Davis, CA
pros: Most student jobs pay more than minimum wage and during the pandemic, the university has managed to keep quite a few employees on board, but not all. Virtually all campus student employees are given incredible flexibility to accommodate for academics.
cons: Even though students generally only work part time, we're subjected to full-time paperwork. There was a recent pay check "scandal" in which numerous students weren't getting paid during an administrative system switch.

review_title: Student Office Assistant at UC Davis Office of Research
pros: Determined and friendly environment. Employer is reasonable with work time and break time, gives enough work and reward to employees. Very social work environment and culture.
cons: Office Assistant job is very demanding, with long hours and lots of stress. The pay deserves to be a bit higher.

pros: Flexible hours that worked with other jobs or time commitments. The staff and management were kind and accepting and fostered a healthy working environment.
cons: Very busy, taxing work. Work was very fast paced and repetitive. Work often left no time for breaks due to the constant flow of customers.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Davis, CA
pros: It is a great a place to work, especially for those who focus on Agricultural research work. Also, it is bike friendly.
cons: Well, I would complain about the weather here since it is very dry and hot in the summer and cool and wet in the winner, just not my favorite.

job_title: UCD TechHub Macbook Salesman, Technician in Davis, CA
pros: On campus, so no need for transportation between work and classes.  Staff and students are very friendly, with occasional exceptions. Excellent for part- time. Amazing coworkers.
cons: Can be stressful at times, do not recommend for someone that cannot work under pressure. Poor directions and low supervision causes mistakes to occur frequently, sometimes with consequences. Poor communication between workers and supervisors.

review_title: Good place to work as a student
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: Hours are quite flexible if you're a student, since most research groups realize that you're also there to learn and attend class. If you play your cards right, chances are that they will pay your tuition.
cons: Pay is not all that great if you're a student, although they did pay my tuition -- that alone is pretty huge if you've already spent a fortune on your undergraduate education.

review_title: Working at your school is extraordinarily convenient.
job_title: Student Assistant IV in Davis, CA
pros: Friendly people; can most likely find a job related to your field, and even if you don't, you'll probably be working with other students which is nice; while you probably won't have a career here, it's really nice to work within biking distance of classes (makes scheduling much easier)
cons: Pay is not the greatest; you might end up practically living on campus (especially if you're an engineer!)

pros:
- Excellent training programs, consulting services, and workshops to equip the Teaching Assistants and maintain a quality education environment.
- Opportunities to teach in many diverse settings, such as lectures, discussion sessions, and wet labs.
- Freedom to experiment with different teaching methods with minimal outside interference.
cons: For a class size over 300 students, the grading process for midterms and finals can be dreadful and take up to 10 hours to finish.

review_title: It was a great position surrounded by good people.  Lots of opportunities for learning and Davis is a good place to live
pros:
The environment is nice.  You can bike, walk, be outdoors.  People are friendly and it is an overall safe place.
It was a great position surrounded by good people.  Lots of opportunities for learning and Davis is a good place to live
cons: There are fluctuations due to the student population.

pros: The provided a friendly working environment where I always felt supported and  where I could ask for help if I needed it. It was a challenging environment, but the kind of challenging that helps you grow as a person
cons: The position I was in took up a good amount of my time and I didn't get much time off.

pros: UCD has a large community of researchers interested in plant sciences who are highly collaborative.
cons: Finding grant money to do applied field research is challenging. Lots of turnover of grad students and interns because of graduation but that's the nature of a University.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Davis, CA
pros: Doing a PHD here after my masters at a different institution. The UC system is thought highly of, and will look good on a resume. Work with friendly people and have access to equipment.
cons: Same atmosphere as the lower ranked university I was at before. I don't understand why the university is ranked higher. The graduate student union only represents the teaching assistants and not the research assistants...

review_title: Great benefits, good security but at an opportunity cost.
pros:
- Cushy
- Great benefits
- Relaxed, university atmosphere
- Work / life balance
- If you're a hard worker, easy to stand out
cons:
- Cushy
- Compensation not competitive to private industry
- Politics can get in the way of results
- Can stifle career development if you get too comfortable

job_title: Lead Event Technician in Davis, CA
pros: Surrounded by student coworkers that become some of your best friends. Flexible hours, great benefits for students, and decent pay. Gives a lot of helpful experience for future endeavors.
cons: During the few busy times during the year, there can be a lot of hours in a given week--can be detrimental if you have midterms or finals or homework, etc.

pros: Great learning environment, great benefits, wonderful people. I learned so much here. I would definitely work for UC Davis again
cons: Some of the cons at UC Davis were based around salary for part time employees, even though it was a great learning environment.

pros: The University of California, Davis, is a major public research university located in Davis, California, just west of Sacramento.
cons: The UC Davis Aggies athletic teams compete in the NCAA Division I level, primarily in the Big West Conference as well as the Big Sky Conference (Football only) and the Mountain Pacific Sports Federation. In its first year of full Division I status, 11 UC Davis teams qualified for NCAA post-season competition.

pros: Mondavi Center was a great place to have a part time job during college.  I felt like my work was important, and learned valuable skills that helped me get hired after I graduated.  Also a flexible schedule and comp tickets
cons: There are certain tedious processes that have developed that can suck your time and energy away.  Otherwise, not many besides the minimum wage.

pros: The students have been lovely and the weather is nice. The land feels very fertile — there’s always fresh produce.
cons: Perhaps I’ve been spoiled, but Davis doesn’t have the “center of the universe” feel you get at Stanford. Some programs are more cutting edge than others — the vet school, for example, is great. The town is liberal and friendly but small and insulated and, as a result, gets stifling quickly.

pros:
Good and smart people, a nice place to work. There are good benefits and a quality atmosphere.
Not high stress.
cons: It's a public university, so funding depends on the state, leading to furloughs and possible layoffs always looming. Not exactly big bucks.

review_title: I am satisfied with my position here at UC Davis, in spite of the ineptitude of the administration.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in Davis, CA
pros: Family-friendly location, collaborative environment, excellent opportunities for networking, and cutting edge research. Overall a healthy work environment for a position in science.
cons: There is plenty of slow administration and bureaucratic non-sense. The benefits are also rather poor. The administration will take advantage of you if you are not careful and aware of your rights.
